get measurement of R&D investment all those other things and the bottom line is total Farm productivity or or profitability it's the key area of big decisions now at the moment with big data we are just a start to give you an idea what's already out there this is the Irish system so the Irish and you think the Irish are a little bit backwards and apologies for those people Irish in the room but they have a lovely piece of legislation that saids if you breed cattle in Ireland you have to be part of that system it's great wouldn't that be great piece of legislation to putr but it means every animal in irland is fully genotyped every animal all the transactions right the way through its lifetime are made when it goes to the avire every piece of information is actually captured it in the avire all of that information fed back into a National Database and that's all made will back up into decision making around genetics and completely integrated right the way through the system you have to be part of that now the really good thing is the Irish tapped into the European Agriculture Commission and they got something like $70 million to install and we don't have the luxury doing that type of area so that's our job New Zealand again system with New Zealand that's about $187 million today now we're talking about in nla about putting a system that's going to cost us $2 to $3 million we're not even in the right ballpark when it comes to these type of decision making so the lesson learned from others about talking thing and we've got a review out at the moment it's about getting everybody in the same room and think about where the wind situations actually are so looking for people to make decisions and outcomes and the real key about integration across the live stock chain is that you've got to create the win-win based on aggregation and aggregation to leads to decisions at the moment Mick might talk about later on about Open Access platforms around data well the real people are asking livestock is open access around the algorithms that involve the decision making because at the moment there is no confidence in a lot of those algorithms that involved the decision Mak so we've got to get to that M no one really knows what big data is everything everybody thinks is going to be important uh everybody's applying a consistent approach and principles to address that there's Democratic data is the delivery through public available apis and everything like that you talk to everybody everybody thinks yes I'm involved in Big Data you talk to everybody about how to using big data on collecting it collecting big data is not using big data everybody wants to be part of it and everybody thinks that because they've got data they've got value in big data and people have yet to work out the only value in data is when you aggregate that data to make a decision and we have got to face a real cultural change in in agriculture about moving away from IP protectionism to an open- Source platform that allows big decisions to be made across agriculture at the moment we're moving the other way down other way around information about genuine value creating genuine value in the supply chain or the value chain is a real critical thing you can make decisions you can give advice on those type of things but unless they lead to tangible value there be no impact on agriculture as I said before data by itself is not valuable and people are putting all of these restrictions around data because they think they own the data the real key is to only algorithms that aggregate the data that's where the real information is going to be collected and actually making the public Source most going and people think that providing data entitles them more value so I've listened and we worked with people recently that said I'm giving you this data and in in return for this data I expect this now in many cases you can't actually predict what you're going to give them so how can you actually give uh take their data without actually understanding what you're going to give them back and that's going to be the learning experience to work over in the next couple years and then industry own data I mean as an RDC about 3 months ago we blindly went into the belief that we should set up a single National Database set up all these algorithms do all these wonderful things control a lot right a lot of consultations power is firstly helping set the standards and secondly helping set the framework about how you create the algorithms to make decisions it's not our role to pull the data together our role is to coordinate and facilitate the opportunity to do that so my challenge for the industries are data is increasingly more complex it's complicated and volumetric and if you think farmers are struggling with day to-day decision making they are they're struggling with draft decisions they're struggling with all these things and suddenly we're going to put this huge pressure on them to cope with the information that's coming back to them and I have already started to see some of the producers struggling and particularly in the sea stock industry struggle with that transition from visual to information driven decisions and that is creating culture Big Data must generate capacity to drive big decisions so I hope everybody walks out the room we're thinking about big decisions rather than big data and the key barriers engaging everybody along the value chain and listening what Phil said earlier about changing the value chain that horizontal platform of information transfer is yet to be discussed because we haven't yet had the real conversation about agriculture about integrating livestock with pastures and cropping and soils everybody's wor walking in their own silos and that big decision about integration has yet to come thanks very much
